You should probably be a tad less concerned with light conditions and more concerned with overwatering plants. It’ll cause then to rot. A lot of plants will tolerate less light as long as you adjust the watering accordingly. Without even knowing the outcomes of this video, if you want a low maintenance plant fo with a snake plant, Hoya, pothos, Chinese evergreen, or spider plant. This video is honestly not the best, it’s unlikely that you or anyone else is living in literally 0 light. You have a window or light source in the room most certainly. Even so, if you’re willing to spend money on buying plants and you really want to increase lighting conditions (e.g. you live in a basement with little natural light or you want to help promote survival over winter when there is less natural light) you can also probably afford a grow light or you can switch out a bulb with a grow light bulb. Since lighting conditions are passive for the most part (you have light or you don’t, you don’t need to remember to take the freaking sun out) a better quantifier for low maintenance plant is watering and fertilizer schedule and how prone they are to pests

I missed one piece of information from your video and I had to search and see if I was right or not. So, in a nutshell: plants do the photosynthesis for making their own "food" (sugars) and they also use oxygen for growth (burning the sugar and trapping carbon as cellulose.)

The dark leaves are the ones discarded during the "burning" process, to keep the most important parts of the plant alive (roots and trunks.) Like in a sinking ship, you can make it buoyant for a longer time if you discard dead weight (I'm not sure if it's the best analogy....)

Now, WHAT IF,... you had put the plants like in a larger area of soil... their roots would have the room to shoot out, to find nutrients elsewhere.. so my thought process is to imagine having to grow plants while having to live like in a cave  system below the earth surface,.. the roots would be able to search for nutrients that are in the soil from the sun light coming from above...  for example if volcanoes erupted and covered our earth, the sun would not be able to penetrate through and it would kill the crops because of it.. however.. im curious if other rays of light would pass through the soot, so technically the plants could still process photosynthesis, through its root system... i guess what i am trying to say is if your house plants had more soil room to stretch out,.. then they wouldnt become cramped up so quickly.. meaning, while living in the sun, the roots are not needed to branch out when they get what they need from the sun and the water, but if you take away the sun and usual water supply, the roots would shoot out quickly in search of nutrients, which can come from the extra soil.. so it may allow them to last even longer,... ultimately, plants need the nutrients, and if they are confined that limits their ability to go find the nutrients.. and that in and of itself can kill them, not just due to the lack of recieving sunlight.. interesting. so i just blabbered on about my thoughts, and long rant ended,... Technically these houseplants didn't have zero light 'cause lightbulbs do in fact produce light that plants can photosynthesize, just at much weaker amounts than sunlight, grow lights ect.
This room being a laundry room that has a higher kelvin and lumen looking led lightbulb in it and laundry rooms being used on a weekly basis, I'd say the title of ZERO LIGHT is scientifically inaccurate.

What I would have suggested for this experiment to be "more scientific" is to use a light meter for the room at the various heights of the shelves (is it pure coincidence that some of the lower shelf plants left the experiment first?) and the general amount of time the light in that room is on during a weekly basis ect as well as testing the humidity of the room and how that changes when laundry is on.

I'm an avid gardener/house plant person who before I had any grow lights and while I was living in a basement, went around my house and tested the light/ lightbulbs I had to see which would be the best to grow seedlings under. Fun Fact: The plants that don't require a lot of water have a very thick cuticle. This is because the cuticle is a waxy part on the blade of the plant, trapping water in to make sure it can survive. Drink photosynthesis guard cells will open up the stomata and a lot of water can be lost that way. In very hot climates the cuticle of the plant is very thick so it can hold water in so it won't completely die when it does photosynthesis later, because during photosynthesis it will lose some of that water. Cacti have some of the thickest cuticles as well. The dryer the climate the plant is the thicker the cuticle.

It's no shock that all the tiny potted plants suffered and withered first and the winning survivors were large potted plants.

Tiny pots = less water in the soil. Large pots = more water in the soil.

This experiment could partially show how long it takes for different sized pots allow evaporation of water IN CONJUNCTION with the nano sipping of water by the plants. Each plant (or colony) sips water at different rates.

To do this right, repot all plants to same size pot and try again same time next year.

I'd also consider using a red-light (used in astrophotography) when checking on the plants because, the few moments the lights were on in the utility room for checkups & laundry, the light given them might have been enough to boost their lives. Smaller plants with fewer leaves couldn't collect as much light as the larger plants with big solar collectors.

Also, with the plants quarantined to a utility room, if there's any humidity from the wet laundry that leaked into the air, that could have also indirectly watered the plants thru the air as well by the means they been doing for gazillions of years by absorption thru the air.

All in all. I think a good starting point for an experiment. Data collected. No real conclusions can be drawn at this time.
